Expectation1: Maintain a friendly and approachable demeanor
Situation1: The acquaintance encounters a person who is visibly upset and crying about a recent event.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Story: I was just about to head back to my desk after grabbing a coffee when I saw Jamie, someone I know from the break room, sitting alone in the hallway, shoulders shaking as she wiped tears from her face. Instinctively, I slowed down, remembering how important it is to be approachable and supportive, especially when someone’s clearly having a rough time. I wanted to sit beside her, offer a listening ear, maybe even a comforting word. But at that exact moment, my phone buzzed with a flurry of Slack notifications—urgent messages from my team. There was a production outage, and the root cause was traced back to a bug in my code. Customers were locked out, and the pressure to fix it was mounting by the second. My mind raced, torn between the expectation to be a good acquaintance and the professional demand to drop everything and troubleshoot. I could feel my heart pounding, guilt and anxiety twisting together as I stood frozen, caught between two worlds, unsure which one needed me more.
